channel.name: Is it possible to send MINA to the token account?

messages.content: Is it possible to send MINA to the token account?
What is this supposed to mean
Token owner? If token owner’s token is MINA, then yes.

Token accounts are seperate accounts in the ledger if I understand correctly. They're a combination of the address and the tokenID. So the MINA token is a token account by deafult. It doesn't make sense to send another type of token to another token account since they're derived differently

You can derive the tokenId recursively, i.e. you can get the tokenId of the (publicKey, tokenId) and then create a token account of the 2nd and 3rd derivation of tokenId. What happens if this tokenId is the default tokenId of MINA?
sorry, I'm getting a little confused. Are you asking what happens when you create a token account with an address and MINA token ID?
Actually, I'm looking for the way to send MINA to NFTs that are minted as a token accounts with verification key installed in the token account.
You can’t

Ah, I don't think it's possible to send MINA to a different token account. Maybe some else can chime in if they have a different answer. But shouldn't the verification key be deployed to the address of that nft token account? can't you just send mina to that address?
You want to create another account where it can receive the funds.
I can send the MINA to this account, but I will have hard time connecting MINA operations to the content of NFT due to the bug https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1245

embeds.title: Accessing two token accounts in one SmartContract's @method causes ...
embeds.description: When @method accesses one token Account(address, tokenId), everything works as expected. When trying to access two token accounts, the following error appears while proving: ● MinaNFT contract › sh...

messages.content: consider just using OCaml
Will it allow to overcome o1js bug?
Probably, I haven’t encountered a single bug yet in pickles

Might be worth mentioning that you probably also won't have the bug if you modify the raw account update in o1js directly, i.e. if you use the same API that you would also have in ocaml.

The bug likely comes from some cashed variable or some other high level API

@DFST to get a sense of where the bug comes from: in the example you linked, does it work if you just use 

token.value.requireEquals(Field(1))
(this version of using it is much simpler, just modifies the account update with a precondition, instead of getting a variable which contains the state)
Actually the whole pattern of instantiating a contract and then only using its state is somewhat ill-defined / not tested
Not sure if it creates the account update in the right way
So what definitely will overcome this bug is creating the account update explicitly, and setting individual state precondition fields

Thank you @Las @gregor ! Great idea, I will try it. I already used this technique for the last MinaNFT contract deployed now to the mainnet. I was looking in the o1js code to understand what AccountUpdates I create when I use o1js methods and then was creating AccountUpdates manually. The reason I was doing so is to decrease the number of AccountUpdates for mint operation; I succeeded to decrease it from 7 to 4 by switching from high-level o1js code to manual AccountUpdate creation (I also better understand what exactly my contract is doing now, too)))

Great that I can use the same technique to overcome the bugs.
look at zeko code to see how account updates work IMO
you should be able to code roughly the same way in o1js probably

```
token.value.requireEquals(Field(1));
```
gives the same error 
```
FieldVector.get(): Index out of bounds, got 9711/9706

      at get (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:2745:13)
      at external_values (src/mina/src/lib/crypto/kimchi_backend/pasta/vesta_based_plonk.ml:95:33)
      at ../../../../../../workspace_root/src/mina/src/lib/crypto/kimchi_backend/common/plonk_constraint_system.ml:980:44
      at iteri$1 (ocaml/base/array0.ml:50:18)
      at _ozi_ (src/mina/src/lib/crypto/kimchi_backend/common/plonk_constraint_system.ml:974:9)
      at ../../../../../../home/trivo/.opam/default/lib/base/list.ml:544:8
      at fold_left$0 (ocaml/ocaml/list.ml:121:25)
      at fold_left$2 (ocaml/base/list0.ml:21:23)
      at iteri$2 (ocaml/base/list.ml:543:6)
      at compute_witness (src/mina/src/lib/crypto/kimchi_backend/common/plonk_constraint_system.ml:973:5)
      at create_async (src/mina/src/lib/crypto/kimchi_backend/pasta/vesta_based_plonk.ml:117:7)
      at create_proof (src/mina/src/lib/pickles/step.ml:830:24)
      at _iD2_ (src/mina/src/lib/pickles/step.ml:836:17)
      at ../../../../../../workspace_root/src/mina/src/lib/promise/js/promise.js:38:29
      at withThreadPool (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:3685:14)
      at prettifyStacktracePromise (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:1936:12)
      at node_modules/o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:21707:14
      at Object.run (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:10112:16)
      at createZkappProof (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:21700:21)
      at addProof (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:21693:15)
      at addMissingProofs (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:21665:42)
      at node_modules/o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:22745:40
      at Object.<anonymous> (experimental/issue_token_accounts-v2.test.ts:268:5)
```
Thanks!

Changing it to the
```
    const update = AccountUpdate.create(address, tokenId);
    update.body.preconditions.account.state[0].value.assertEquals(Field(0));
```
allows the contract to be compiled and the precondition to be satisfied for any value, i.e. I set the value to Field(1) and the precondition that it should be Field(0) is satisfied.

Changing the code to any value other than Field(0), i.e.
```
    const update = AccountUpdate.create(address, tokenId);
    update.body.preconditions.account.state[0].value.assertEquals(Field(1));
```
cause the contract compilation fail:
```
    Field.assertEquals(): 0 != 1

      at _Field.assertEquals (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:7104:17)
      at Token.checkFail (experimental/issue_token_accounts-v2.test.ts:82:54)
      at Token.wrappedMethod (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:24238:52)
      at node_modules/o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:24841:63
      at node_modules/o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:9851:12
      at Object.constraintSystem (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:4565:11)
      at Function.analyzeMethods (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:24839:50)
      at Function.compile (o1js/dist/node/index.cjs:24492:23)
      at Object.<anonymous> (experimental/issue_token_accounts-v2.test.ts:110:36)
```
https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-lib/blob/master/experimental/issue_token_accounts-v2.test.ts
It actually checks that the precondition is satisfied and give correct results!
Yeah exactly you have to modify the precondition on the account update, not assert its value

In SmartContract `this.address` is a constrained value? Can I rely on it to create a AccountUpdate:
```
const update = AccountUpdate.create(this.address, tokenId);
```

It's constrained in the sense that it's the same public key that's on the 'this' account update. I.e. has to match the address of the contract for the proof to verify against the verification key on that contract. (It's not hard coded in the circuit though, so you can e.g. deploy the same contract to different public keys)

If I deploy the same contract to two different public keys A and B, is it possible to constrain the proof to be valid only for the public key A and invalid for B?

I understand that it is possible by writing to the contract state the address of the contract and then verifying the state to be the same as this.address, but is it possible to do without spending 2 of 8 Fields in the contract state?
you could make the address public input
What do you mean by the public input? I understand that public input exists in ZkProgram, but when I send tx to the SmartContract account, I have only proof authorization and preconditions.
oh right I'm dumb.
But you can still achieve what you want AFAICT.
@DFST what's the point anyway?
You don't want to be able to reuse the proof on another account?
You can't anyway already.
I want to disable the possibility to generate a proof that use the AccountUpdate precondition for the wrong pair {address, tokenId} by replacing the this.address in the tx.
you can just check that it's equal to a constant?
you could even check that it's equal to a constant _only when proving_

Theoretically yes, but it means that if I want to deploy this contract to many accounts, the verification keys will be different and I will be unable to use pre-computed verification keys and prover keys and it will slow the process significantly.

The address is already part of the account update, which is the public input. So the proof already commits to the address. The same proof can't be sent to a different address, which sounds like what you want to protect against?
I’m honestly not sure what you’re trying to do
